Award.AwardTitle: RCN: The Novus Project for Integrating Paleo- and Neo-ecosystem Ecology
Award.AbstractNarration:
By their very nature, events such as beetle outbreaks, catastrophic fires, large windstorms, and severe droughts are considered to be disturbances. Although it is now understood that some ecosystems require certain kinds of disturbance, there are no general rules about how ecosystems respond to disturbance. As a result, it is difficult to develop strategies for dealing with disturbances, which are in some ecosystems becoming more frequent and more severe as a consequence of changing climates. The Novus network will bring together groups of scientists who study different types of disturbance, and in particular scientists who have studied the impacts and consequences of disturbance on different time scales, with the goal of coordinating and promoting research about ecosystem responses to disturbance. An important contribution of the network will be to enhance communication between scientists studying contemporary ecosystem responses to disturbance and scientists studying historical responses at time scales of hundreds to thousands of years ago.
The network will conduct four workshops, develop an interactive website (www.ksu.edu/novus), jointly mentor a postdoctoral researcher, publish collaborative manuscripts, organize sessions at scientific meetings, and foster a science exchange program. Additionally, data will be added to a public database, making them widely available. The network will engage and train young scientists, share information about new developments in methods, and interact with government agencies and NGOs to provide information about the effects of disturbance (especially insect outbreaks and wildland fire management). Participants will be recruited to the network through broad solicitation efforts and a variety of mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Novus Research Coordination Network is to unify records of disturbance and ecosystem response over multiple timescales. The Novus RCN achieved this goal by synthesizing data of post-disturbance ecosystem responses, integrating these data with biogeochemical models, coordinating new research by connecting ecologists and paleo-ecologists, and by providing training and mentorship to young scientists. The main impact of this project is the idea of temporal scaling in ecology. Secondarily, we have made contributions to the discipline of disturbance ecology, particularly the ideas of recovery interval and constructive disturbances. There have been impacts on other disciplines through expanding the timescale of long-term ecological research to include hundreds and thousands of years. We developed new techniques in paleoecology and dendrochronology to better assess ecosystem processes. Finally, this project created a diverse network of researchers all focused on biogeochemical response to disturbance. These researchers are engaged in a variety of active and ongoing new collaborations.

 

Several types of training and outreach were also achieved with this grant. (1) There was direct training and mentoring of four postdoctoral associates in this project. These postdoctoral associates successfully conducted research, presented it at scientific meetings, and attained professional positions. This high-quality training helped prepare the workforce at both public universities and the private sector. (2) A scientist exchange program allowed more junior scientists to visit the lab of a more senior scientist to collaborate on a project of mutual interest. The Novus RCN supported eight such projects, to develop specialized technical and intellectual skills through these exchanges. (3) A total of four workshops were held at locations across the U.S. including Oregon, Colorado, Minnesota, and New Hampshire. During these four workshops, a total of over 100 participants from approximately 12 nations were involved, representing a large amount of scientific talent and a diverse range of perspectives. (4) The Novus website included a blog that posted about job openings, science communication, upcoming meetings, and papers and research updates of interest to the group. The website is open to the public and contains a mechanism to join the network as well as contact information for the steering committee.
